DOCNAME: CASE OF GISELA MULLER v. GERMANY
CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 6-1;Pecuniary damage - claim dismissed;Non-pecuniary damage - finding of violation sufficient;Costs and expenses partial award - domestic proceedings;Costs and expenses partial award - Convention proceedings
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in PERSON in GPE .

CARDINAL . Since DATE the applicant , her sister PERSON and their mother PERSON were the joint owners of a plot of land situated in GPE . The lease of the plot was managed by a partnership consisting of the applicant , PERSON , S. and a limited company ( S company ) . Partners of the S company were also the applicant , PERSON DATE , serious arguments arose between the applicant on one side and her mother and sister on the other side about questions of the proper administration of the partnership , in particular in respect of taxation matters .

CARDINAL . By letter dated DATE , the applicant filed an action with ORG ( ORG ) , sitting as a court competent in commercial matters ( PERSON für GPE ) , against PERSON the S company ( hereafter “ the defendants ” ) . According to the Government ’s submissions – which are contested by the applicant – ORG received the action on DATE . The applicant asked ORG to prohibit the defendants from excluding her from the management of the business . She also demanded that the defendants surrender all DATE accounts since DATE and that they distribute the net profits accordingly . The applicant alleged that the defendants had failed to consult her about the management . She further complained about mistakes in the management , in particular about the fact that the defendants insisted on paying business taxes without being obliged to do so .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant ’s counsel stated that the applicant was willing to reach a friendly settlement .
CARDINAL . On DATE , during a first oral hearing , the parties declared that they were willing to reach an understanding and only thereafter hold another hearing .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant ’s counsel informed ORG that negotiations on a settlement had not taken place .

CARDINAL . On DATE , during a further hearing , ORG continuing efforts to induce the parties to agree on a friendly settlement failed . However , PERSON agreed to submit all documents on the DATE accounts since DATE to the applicant ’s counsel for inspection .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant ’s counsel informed ORG that S. had failed to comply .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG scheduled an oral hearing which was subsequently postponed on the applicant ’s request .
CARDINAL . On DATE agreed to submit the relevant documents on the DATE accounts since DATE to the applicant ’s counsel .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG instructed the defendants to submit the partnership agreements and the DATE accounts since DATE and to disclose the use of the reported profits . It further instructed the applicant to quantify her claims .

CARDINAL . In DATE and DATE and DATE ORG called for the case - file of a separate law suit which the applicant conducted against the partnership ’s former tax consultant . On DATE according to the ORG ’s submissions , which are contested by the applicant – the defendants submitted the DATE balances and reported on the use of the profits .

CARDINAL . On DATE the presiding judge noted that “ particularly on emotional grounds , the sensible pursuit of progress in this case ” was not possible before a final decision had been reached in the proceedings against the tax consultant .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant complied with the conditions imposed in the order of CARDINAL DATE . In DATE and DATE , DATE and DATE ORG filed for further information on the proceedings against the tax consultant .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG scheduled a further hearing for DATE . On DATE that court decided to schedule a further hearing only after the tax authority ’s decisions on the partnership ’s tax liability for DATE had become final . On DATE the applicant ’s counsel informed the court that the tax decisions had become final . On DATE , DATE and CARDINAL DATE the applicant ’s counsel requested ORG to schedule a new oral hearing . On DATE ORG scheduled an oral hearing for DATE , noting that the delay was owed to the chamber ’s excessive workload during DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE , following the oral hearing , ORG delivered a partial decision ordering the defendants to pay ORG to the applicant and to grant her a restricted power over the commercial partnership ’s bank accounts .
CARDINAL . NORP In a letter directed to the presiding judge of ORG , the presiding judge of ORG expressed his regrets of the fact that his attempts to reconcile the parties had failed .
CARDINAL . On DATE the defendants lodged an appeal against ORG partial decision .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ( ORG in GPE ) , having received submissions from both parties , scheduled an oral hearing for CARDINAL DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant informed ORG that she had changed counsel .
CARDINAL . On DATE and CARDINAL DATE ORG postponed the hearing , once following the applicant ’s request and a second time because of the rapporteur ’s illness .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG further postponed the hearing on the ground that the rapporteur had been seconded to the eastern part of GPE .
CARDINAL . On DATE , following an oral hearing on DATE , ORG of Appeal quashed ORG partial decision and rejected the applicant ’s claims .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG scheduled an oral hearing for DATE . On DATE and DATE , following requests from the defendants , ORG postponed the hearing .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG , once again , tried to induce the parties to reach a friendly settlement . On DATE the parties informed ORG that no settlement had been reached .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ordered the preparation of an expert opinion as to whether the DATE accounts for DATE of both the commercial partnership and ORG had been prepared in accordance with the rules on accounting and balances . It found that the DATE balances did not form a sufficient basis to calculate the applicant ’s possible net profit claims .
CARDINAL . On DATE , upon payment of the advance costs , ORG sent the files to ORG for the nomination of a suitable expert .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant ’s counsel informed ORG that he had relinquished his mandate .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG named an expert .

CARDINAL . On DATE according to the Government ’s submissions – the presiding judge of ORG orally informed the applicant that he would only commission the expert after she had nominated a new counsel .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant informed ORG that she had mandated new counsel .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ordered the parties to pay further advance costs .
CARDINAL . NORP On DATE ORG appointed the certified accountant NORP to prepare the expert opinion .
CARDINAL . On DATE , after having received the necessary documents towards DATE , NORP submitted his report .

CARDINAL . On DATE , following the submissions of both parties and requests filed by the defendants to postpone the hearing , ORG held an oral hearing and asked NORP to amend his report in view of supplementary documents to be submitted by the defendants .
CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE the applicant lodged a criminal charge against the defendants for withholding documents , which led to a search of S. ’s apartment .

CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE – according to ORG submissions – ORG requested ORG to transmit the case - file . On DATE the presiding judge of ORG informed the parties that he was prevented from pursuing proceedings as ORG had not yet returned the case - file .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG asked NORP to resume his work on the amendment of his expert report .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant addressed a letter to the President of ORG , referring to the excessive length of proceedings and requesting that her case be given priority .

CARDINAL . On DATE the presiding judge of ORG informed the parties that he was unable to proceed because the files had not yet returned from the President ’s office . On DATE the President informed the applicant that he could not find any delay in proceedings attributable to the court .
CARDINAL . On DATE the expert informed ORG that the defendants had not submitted all necessary documents .
DATE . On DATE , during an oral hearing , the defendants stated that they would submit the requested documents at DATE . ORG scheduled a date to proclaim a decision for CARDINAL DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant requested the oral hearing to be reopened and announced new applications .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG re - opened proceedings and scheduled a hearing for DATE . On DATE , following the defendant ’s request of CARDINAL DATE , ORG postponed the hearing to DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG suggested another friendly settlement and scheduled a final hearing for DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE , following the defendant ’s request , ORG postponed the hearing to DATE . Following that hearing ORG announced that it would issue a decision on DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG received NORP ’s amended expert opinion .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ordered the parties to file their comments on the report and scheduled to give a decision on DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG issued a judgment combined with a judgment on the basis of the cause of action ( ORG ) , concluding that the applicant had effectively revoked the managerial rights of the defendants , that the defendants – in collaboration with the applicant – were obliged to draw up the DATE accounts from DATE and rejecting the majority of the applicant ’s further claims . In his reasoning , the presiding judge noted that the parties conducted their arguments since DATE “ with consistent stubbornness and with an uncompromising attitude ” the like of which he – the presiding judge DATE had never before experienced in his professional career .

CARDINAL . On DATE and CARDINAL DATE all parties lodged their appeals . On DATE , having received submissions from all parties , ORG scheduled a hearing for DATE . On DATE , following a request by the applicant , ORG postponed the hearing to DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG suggested that the parties should seek a separation . At the end of the hearing , following the request of all parties , the court decided that proceedings should only be continued on request of CARDINAL of the parties .

CARDINAL . On DATE , following the defendants’ application in a separate proceeding , ORG ( ORG ) ordered that the piece of land administered by the commercial partnership be sold by compulsory auction with a view to partitioning the property concerned ( ORG ) .
CARDINAL . On DATE , following the applicant ’s request to continue proceedings , ORG scheduled an oral hearing for DATE which was later postponed on the GPE request to CARDINAL DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG announced its intention to suspend proceedings until the termination of the auction proceedings , against which the applicant protested .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG passed an order to suspend the proceedings until a final decision had been reached in the auction proceedings . ORG found that the outcome of at least part of the lawsuit depended on the conclusion of these auction proceedings . On DATE and DATE and DATE and DATE ORG rejected the applicant ’s requests to resume proceedings on the ground that the auction proceedings had not yet been terminated .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant raised a constitutional complaint . She complained that despite the undue length of the proceedings , ORG refused to resume them . She also gave a chronological account of the proceedings and maintained that their excessive length had violated her rights under LAW .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ( Bundesverfassungsgericht ) refused to entertain the applicant ’s complaint .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG , in separate proceedings , rejected the applicant ’s final complaint against the compulsory sale of the plot of land . On this occasion , ORG was sitting as the same chamber as in the above mentioned proceedings .
CARDINAL . On DATE passed away .

CARDINAL . By an undated letter dispatched on DATE the presiding judge of ORG referred to this ORG ’s decision on the admissibility of the present complaint and asked the applicant if she wished to pursue the proceedings .
DATE . By letter of CARDINAL DATE the applicant insisted that ORG was legally obliged to revoke its suspension order of CARDINAL DATE before pursuing proceedings .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG lifted its suspension order and scheduled an oral hearing for DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE , following the oral hearing , ORG suspended the proceedings against S. because of the latter ’s death . At the same time , ORG issued CARDINAL pages of legal assessment of the case and invited the parties to submit any comments they would like to make within DATE . A new hearing would be scheduled after expiry of this time - limit . The proceedings are still pending before ORG .
CARDINAL . On DATE , upon the applicant ’s complaint , ORG revoked the auction order . On DATE this decision was set aside by ORG ; a further appeal was dismissed on DATE by ORG .
CARDINAL . The applicant ’s various further motions aimed at the prevention of the sale of the plot , including a further constitutional complaint , remained unsuccessful .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ordered the auction of the plot of land . It was purchased by LAW The applicant ’s complaints remained unsuccessful ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) .
CARDINAL . The relevant Rules of Civil Procedure on the suspension of proceedings read as follows :

“ The court may order , if the decision of the legal dispute wholly or partly depends on the existence or non - existence of a legal relationship which forms the subject of another pending legal dispute ... that the proceedings be suspended until the other legal dispute is settled ... ”
“ The court may lift its orders of suspension ... ”
“ Suspended or interrupted proceedings are resumed by filing a statement with the court which is then served on the other party . ”
“ A decision by which the suspension of proceedings is ordered or denied on the ground of provisions of this title ... may be appealed ... ”
“ ( CARDINAL ) Against the decisions of the courts of appeal , no appeal is admissible ... ”
